instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3_OUT: What is PPVRTC_G3_OUT? PPVRTC_G3_OUT is a 3.3v power line that comes out of the clock chip. .
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_SO: What is PP3V3_SO? PP3V3_SO is a typo of PP3V3_S0.
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange ok, no fan spin
threads.message:
hi everyone.

i got that board from customer. he said liquid spill.

i have 12.54V so smc is working

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is 3.3V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is 5.0V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> is 0V

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> I get spices of 3.43V every about 3sec.

I found corrosion aroud <CHIP>U8330</CHIP> but i think thats is not important now

next spot is around U 1900, but <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3_OUT</SIGNAL> is nice 3.42V and 
<SIGNAL>PCH_CLK32K_RTCX</SIGNAL>! is a nice signal , 

that should be so because i have spikes on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, means the RTC is working

around <CHIP>U8005</CHIP> is not like it should look. 

i measured y1915, the 24Mhz signal is coming but frequently like the spikes from <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>


where to start here for the best?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange ok, no fan spin
threads.message: Voltage on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>? Does <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> pulse? If not check the resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange ok, no fan spin
threads.message:
thanks for help.

 <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> is 4.95V pulsing as well

 <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> is not pulsing, 0V

Reesistance to ground  is about 12kohm
in diode mode is 0.390, another same board has here .402

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange ok, no fan spin
threads.message:
Fan does not spin on this model when it powers on, just fyi.

Definitely clean up the area you mentioned was 'ugly', then check for shorts across all rails (probably s3/s0 in this case) if you do in fact have a pulsing rail(s).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange ok, no fan spin
threads.message: the board is still not cleaned should i do this st first?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange ok, no fan spin
threads.message: I don't like to clean boards before repairing them, but you can if you want. If the liquid damage is spot/minor, then I don't clean. If you see liquid across the board or in 4-5 spots, then cleaning it won't hurt. I repair, then clean last.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange ok, no fan spin
threads.message: It is power cycling. Could be anything at this point. Clean up the visible crap and replace <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> if there was corrosion there. Crap under SMC is also likely.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange ok, no fan spin
threads.message:
cleaned in ultrasonic and replaced <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, there was crap under it and 2 traces coroded Pin 13 and Pin 1
so i repaired that and now i get pulsing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> and pulsing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> but no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>
I measured in diode mode <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SO</SIGNAL> to gnd and get a short. so i will look for that (injecting that voltage in that rail and report back.

the smc is near <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> but it looks not bad around it.

EDIT: there is no short in <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, i just a measure error. 
No short in PP3V§_S0 but no voltage and no pulsing here.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange ok, no fan spin
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_FET</SIGNAL> is pulsing 3.3V

<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> is 3-41V stable
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 3.36V stable

<SIGNAL>PCH_CLK24M_XTALOUT</SIGNAL> is nice 24Mhz but pulsing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange ok, no fan spin
threads.message: CPU Vcore pulsing too? <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> doing anything?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange ok, no fan spin
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is pulsing with 3.3V

<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is 0V, not pulsing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange ok, no fan spin
threads.message: <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> inspected for corrosion? Possibly crap under SMC too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange ok, no fan spin
threads.message:
checked <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, no corrosion to see. to be shure i gave it a nice reflow

pin 1-3, pin 5-7 are pulsing

reballing smc, here no crap to see as well

after reflow <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and reballing the smc there is no change. problem is still the same. :-(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange ok, no fan spin
threads.message: Is CPU Vcore shorted? <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> traces and termination resistors checked?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange ok, no fan spin
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C1031</CAPACITOR> Pin 1 I get only 0.7Ohm to gnd, on a good board i have 27Ohm, seems to be shorted.

is it a good idea to incect here 1.8V and look with the thermo cam? i am not sure about the voltage value?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange ok, no fan spin
threads.message: yeah 0.7Ohm on CPU Vcore is a fried CPU. Forget about injecting voltage as the CPU will always heat up, even a good one will get warm as the resistance is low enough for that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green/orange ok, no fan spin
threads.message: ok, so that is trash :-) thanks for your help.
